awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Madagascar Caves and Paleoclimate (MADCAP), Investigating Climate Variability in the Southern Hemisphere of the Western Indian Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will produce educational materials and exhibits prepared for a general audience and displayed in a modest museum now under construction at Tsimanampetsotse National Park. The displays will reveal how research with stalagmites helps uncover the climate and vegetation history of Madagascar and will help heighten public awareness of the Park's natural history and biodiversity. This project will involve several Malagasy scientists and includes mentoring for a doctoral student and post-doctoral scholar.  The project will also support research and laboratory experiences for undergraduates at both MIT and UMass. Finally, a better understanding of the causes of decadal-scale climate variability will help in providing insights into potential future changes in rainfall in a country that experiences severe drought and flooding on inter-annual time scales.

The aims of the research are: 1) to investigate sub-decadal to annual resolution changes in precipitation over the past 2,000 years and determine the relationships between precipitation in Madagascar and variability in the Indian Ocean Zonal Mode, El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and other drivers of inter-annual and decadal-scale climate variability; 2) investigate the relationships between climate, landscape evolution and the disappearance of Madagascar's endemic megafauna in the Late Holocene; and 3) investigate the timing and nature of millennial and orbital scale variability in the Indian Ocean Monsoon in the Southern Hemisphere and determine how it relates to Northern Hemisphere Monsoon variability and climate changes in East Africa.

This project aims to use speleothems from caves at two locations in Madagascar to reconstruct climate and landscape evolution in the Late Pleistocene and Holocene. High-resolution time series of speleothem delta 18-Oxygen and Strontium/Calcium and Magnesium/Calcium trace element ratios measured on stalagmites collected from northwest and southwest Madagascar will be used to reconstruct past changes in precipitation.  Speleothem delta 13-Carbon measurements will be used as a proxy for the evolution of the landscape between forest and grassland. Precise age models will be constructed using 230 Thorium/Uranium.

por.por_cntn:
Our research in Madagascar uses geochemical analyses, mainly oxygen isotope ratios, of stalagmites as proxies for past changes in rainfall. We work in two areas of the country, the rainy northwest and the much drier southwest. The great majority of rainfall in Madagascar falls during the summer and is strongly influenced by the seasonal migration of the tropical rainfall belt, which follows the summer season north and south of the equator. All of our work is done with permission from several Malagasy government ministries and in conjunction with Malagasy colleagues and students.  

 

In Northwest Madagascar our climate records extend back to about 25,000 years. The cycles of rainfall we find show a surprising pattern: they vary in phase with similar records form the Northern Hemisphere side of the Indian Ocean. That is when we find wetter periods in northwest Madagascar, it is also wetter in east Africa and southern Arabia. Current theory holds that the Northern and Southern Hemispheres should vary in opposite senses due to migration of the mean position of the tropical rainfall belt north or south. Our results indicate that in the western Indian Ocean region at least, tropical sea surface temperatures control rainfall on both sides of the equator, with warmer sea temperatures leading to increased rainfall.

 

The southwest of Madagascar is relatively dry and growth of stalagmites is intermittent. We have used periods in which stalagmites did grow as indicators of wet periods over the past ~120,000 years. For most of this time the earth was in glacial period with cooler drier conditions everywhere. Our results show that wet periods in the southwest occurred only when summer insolation was high and temperatures in the high southern latitudes were warm. The conjunction of these conditions drew the southern margin of the rainfall belt to the south providing sufficient rain for stalagmites to grow. This influence of temperature in the high southern latitudes on the rainfall belt has not been well documented in other areas.

 

Our climate records have important implications for dramatic changes in Madagascar’s landscape and the decline and ultimate disappearance of Madagascar’s megafauna, a group of large vertebrates including giant lemurs and the elephant bird that are now extinct. Working together with anthropologists we developed the ‘subsistence shift hypothesis’, which says that the introduction of cattle to Madagascar about 1000 years ago had two profound affects. First, it was associated with the introduction of fire as an agricultural tool. Fire was used to turn the original open woodland of Madagascar into a grassy savannah, the grass providing fodder for cattle. The loss of open woodland meant the loss of necessary habitat for many tree dwelling animals such as lemurs. Second, cattle are a significant element of Malagasy diet and the introduction of cattle helped allow the population to grow significantly. People arrived in Madagascar perhaps as long as 10,000 years ago, but only when the population grew rapidly was great enough pressure put on the megafauna to result in their extinction.
